sources.name: Huberman & Minns (2007) – The times they are not changin’: Days and hours of work in Old and New Worlds, 1870–2000. Explorations in Economic History. (Weekly Work Hours)
sources.description:
Description:
Data published by Huberman & Minns (2007) – The times they are not changin’: Days and hours of work in Old and New Worlds, 1870–2000. Explorations in Economic History, 44(4):538–567.

Data publisher's source

The original sources according to Hubermann & Minns (2007):

1870–1913: Huberman (2004); 1929–1938, ILO (1934–38), except for Canada (Ostry and Zaidi, 1972), U.S. (Jones, 1963 and Owen, 1988), and for Australia (Butlin, 1977); the values for Spain in 1938 are for 1936;

1950–1980: ILO (1950–80), except for U.S. (McGratten and Rogerson, 2004), and Australia ( Butlin, 1977);

1980–2000: ILO (2005), except for U.S. (McGratten and Rogerson, 2004), Canada (Heisz and LaRochelle-Côté, 2003), and Denmark (Eurostat, 1995).

LinkThe paper is online here http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0014498307000058

variables.name: Huberman & Minns (2007) – The times they are not changin’: Days and hours of work in Old and New Worlds, 1870–2000. Explorations in Economic History. (Weekly Work Hours)
variables.description:
Data refers to full-time production workers (male and female) in non-agricultural activities.
Only for 2000 Huberman & Minns give estimates for both genders 
separately. I have calculated and visualized the average of the two 
measures.
